title: China demands 'severe punishment' for culprits after 39 bodies found in lorry
text:

China has called on Britain to seek "severe punishment" for those involved in the deaths of 39 people found in a lorry container in Essex.

A major state-backed paper said Britain should bear some responsibility for the case, believed to include victims who were Chinese nationals.

Paramedics and police found the bodies of 31 men and eight women on Wednesday after receiving a call to an industrial estate in Grays.

Police at first thought the victims were all Chinese but at least six Vietnamese families fear their loved ones are among the dead.

Essex Police are questioning four people in relation to the case as the force continues to investigate the deaths.

(Image: Peter Powell)

A 25-year-old man from Northern Ireland who was driving the lorry when the bodies were found is being held in custody.

Mo Robinson was arrested on Wednesday on suspicion of murder after the victims were found dead in the container.

It is believed most, if not all, the victims were dead when he picked up the container. The discovery was made a short time later at the Waterglade Industrial Park after a call was made to emergency services.

Police are also questioning Joanna and Thomas Maher on suspicion of people trafficking and 39 counts of manslaughter.

Hours earlier they told the Mirror they previously owned the Scania lorry cab.

The Mahers said they sold the Bulgarian-registered vehicle a year ago to a company in Ireland.

Mr Maher said he contacted police after news of the lorry deaths broke.

Police revealed on Friday they had also detained a 48-year-old man at Stansted Airport on suspicion of manslaughter and conspiracy to traffic people.

Police investigating on Friday night declined to speculate on reports of the suspected Vietnamese victims.

Some Vietnamese families have shared their fears their relatives were in the lorry container.

They included the distraught family of one woman thought to be among the dead who sent a harrowing final text message to her mother late on Tuesday night.

Pham Thi Tra My, 26, wrote: “I’m sorry Mum. My journey abroad hasn’t succeeded. Mum, I love you so much. I’m dying because I can’t breathe.”

For years, illegal immigrants have stowed away in lorries while attempting to reach Britain, often from the European mainland.

In 2000, 58 Chinese nationals were found dead in a tomato lorry at the port of Dover.

(Image: Twitter)

(Image: Facebook)

Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying said UK police were still carrying out their verification work and at present are not able to verify the nationalities of the deceased.

"We hope that the British side can as soon as possible confirm and verify the identities of the victims, ascertain what happened and severely punish criminals involved in the case," she told a daily news briefing.

Hua said that no matter where the victims were from, the case was an enormous tragedy.

The international community should strengthen their cooperation on fighting illegal immigration and on communication and intelligence to prevent such incidents from happening again, she said.

The Chinese embassy in London said it has sent a team to Essex to coordinate with the police.

Reuters reports that the widely-read Chinese tabloid the Global Times said in a Friday editorial that at the moment it was impossible to say how much responsibility the dead should bear for the tragedy.

(Image: PA)

(Image: PA)

"But such a serious humanitarian disaster has occurred under the eyes of the British and Europeans," it said. "It is clear that Britain and relevant European countries have not fulfilled their responsibility to protect these people from such a death."

Even if the victims were found to have been smuggled into the country, their deaths were not their fault, added the paper, which is published by the ruling Communist Party's official People's Daily.

"We hope that Britain and European countries will put into effect their various commitments to human rights and make due efforts for Chinese people to be free from abuse and sudden death."

Britain appears not to have learned its lesson from the Dover incident two decades ago, it added.

"Imagine how thoroughly European countries would take measures if dozens of Europeans were collectively tragically killed in some way," the paper said.

"Could the British and European people ask themselves why they have not been able to avoid a similar tragedy...Did they take all the serious remedial action that they could have?"
description: China's state-backed newspaper wrote that the deaths of 39 migrants in the back of a lorry was a tragedy that happened "under the eyes of the British and Europeans"
